abstracts.cdata!:
This document presents an analysis of
            environmental and resettlement issues for the third Poverty
            Reduction Support Credit (PRSC3) Project for Uganda. This EA
            repeats the previous impact and mitigation considerations of
            the previous EA for PRSC2, and adds more details regarding
            resettlement and pesticides. Degradation of environmental
            and natural resources is anticipated in the form of
            deforestation, loss of natural habitats, loss of top soil,
            uncontrolled growth of water hyacinths, pollution of water
            bodies, and brush land burning. Environmental regulations
            recommend for ecologically sensitive areas that the
            following measures be taken: use of appropriate farming
            methods, curbing of soil erosion, and protection of water
            catchments. The National Environmental Statute of 1995
            (NEMA) prohibits activities that will reclaim and drain the
            wetlands; and limits other human activities in the wetlands.
            In the same manner it also prohibits activities that will
            lead to destruction of forest and hillsides areas. Measures
            to mitigate potential adverse impacts of pesticide use will
            be taken through the ongoing National Agriculture Advisory
            Services Project (NAADS) and include training of input
            suppliers, and farmers and service providers as well as the
            promotion of alternative pest management methods, including
            best mix of biological or cultural controls. Health care
            waste management considerations related to the health care
            facilities include: raising awareness , developing an
            integrated management plan, ensuring segregation of special
            HCW from other waste, determining appropriate treatment
            technology and disposal site for facility, ensuring proper
            packaging, storage, and transport of special HCW, training
            health care workers, and addressing scavenging issues.
            Checklists identify other potential environmental issues
            such as borehole drilling for water supply, expanding and
            improving the existing water supply, latrine, other
            sanitation facilities, and wastewater treatment.
